content: I was recently awarded the EU funded Marie Skłodowska-Curie fellowship and am working as a postdoctoral researcher at Lund University in Sweden. My research currently focuses on using techniques from statistical field theory and quantum information to explore various aspects of quantum thermodynamics.

title: Dr. Konstantin Nestmann

summary: We published the open-source library _RealTimeTransport_, which allows to compute both stationary and transient transport observables for generic quantum systems connected to metallic reservoirs. [→ Link to GitHub](https://github.com/kn-code/RealTimeTransport/)
title: RealTimeTransport: An open-source C++ library for quantum transport simulations in the strong coupling regime

summary: Workshop: Quantum Many-Body Methods in Condensed Matter Systems, RWTH Aachen
title: Temperature Flow Renormalization Group for Open Quantum Systems

summary: Zoom Group Seminar A. Lunghi (Trinity College Dublin)
title: Time (non)-local Descriptions of Open Quantum System Dynamics
Open Quantum Systems: Time (non)-locality, Fixed Points, and Renormalization Groups

summary: In my doctoral thesis I considered the dynamics of open quantum systems from the quite different perspectives of quantum information theory and statistical physics.
title: Open Quantum Systems: Time (non)-locality, Fixed Points, and Renormalization Groups

summary: We develop the $T$-flow renormalization group scheme to access the low-temperature many-body physics of open quantum systems by literally lowering the temperature of the environment.
title: Renormalization group for open quantum systems using environment temperature as flow parameter

summary: We show how to translate a perturbation expansion for the easier to compute time-nonlocal memory kernel $\mathcal{K}$ into a corresponding expansion for the more complicated time-local generator $\mathcal{G}$.
title: General connection between time-local and time-nonlocal perturbation expansions

summary: We present intriguing exact relations between quantities that describe the time-evolution of quite generic open quantum systems. Combined with our fixed-point equation this leads to powerful insights into various approximation strategies.
title: Fermionic duality: General symmetry of open systems with strong dissipation and memory

summary: We establish that the general connection between time-local and non-local quantum master equations is a simple yet general fixed-point equation with far reaching applications. → See press releases by [RWTH Aachen](https://www.rwth-aachen.de/cms/root/Die-RWTH/Aktuell/Pressemitteilungen/Mai/~oofov/Wie-Quantenbauelemente-ihr-Gedaechtnis-b/?lidx=1), [FZ Jülich](https://www.fz-juelich.de/SharedDocs/Pressemitteilungen/UK/EN/2021/notifications/2021-06-01-quantum-memory.html) and [JARA](https://www.jara.org/en/research/fit/news/detail/how-quantum-devices-keep-their-memory)
title: How quantum evolution with memory is generated in a time-local way

summary: We show that the "trivial" resonant level model actually provides a rich source of examples for interesting dynamics by solving it in 5 different ways.
title: Five approaches to exact open-system dynamics: Complete positivity, divisibility, and time-dependent observables
